Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Early transition metal catalysts for the hydroamination reaction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Kai C. Hulzsch of Rutgers University New Brunswick is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry to develop novel rare earth and group 4 metal based catalyst systems for the hydroamination reaction, with particular attention given to stereochemical aspects of this transformation. A key goal of this project is to identify catalysts that combine high catalytic activity and consistent high stereoselectivity for a broad range of substrates. A broad substrate screening with particular emphasis on functional group tolerance will be accompanied by mechanistic and kinetic means to elucidate the structure of reaction intermediates and develop models for the transition states.
The hydroamination reaction represents a highly valuable transformation that promises to revolutionize the synthesis of nitrogen containing molecules, with potential applications in the syntheses of nitrogen containing basic and fine chemicals, as well as pharmaceuticals, directly from petrochemical feedstock.
Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in state of the art synthetic techniques, and will be exposed to a variety of spectroscopic techniques including multidimensional NMR, and a mutual exchange program with universities in Germany will be developed to increase cultural and social exchange between US and German students.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was the development of environmentally friendly (“green”) approaches for the synthesis of industrially important class of nitrogen-containing organic compounds (“amines”), which are valuable and commercially important bulk chemicals, specialty chemicals, and pharmaceuticals. Classical methods for their synthesis require multiple reaction steps using refined and expensive starting materials and generate significant amount of waste. Many of these compounds exist in two forms that can be described as image and mirror image (similar to a left and right hand). The ability to synthesize these compounds selectively (only one of the two forms) in a single reaction offers not only a significant economic advantage, but also allows for a significant reduction in the environmental footprint of chemical industry.

The investigation focused on the development of catalysts for two types of reactions that allow the preparation of nitrogen-containing organic compounds directly from simple and cheap starting materials without formation of waste or undesired by-products. Both processes utilize the same kind of starting material, but differ in the way the two molecules of the starting material are connected to each other in the process. The first process, the so-called “hydroamination” reaction, involves the addition of an amine nitrogen-hydrogen bond across an unsaturated carbon-carbon bond (Figure 1, the newly formed carbon-nitrogen bond is depicted in red). The second process, the so-called “hydroaminoalkylation” reaction, utilizes a carbon-hydrogen bond located near an amino group, leading to a new carbon-carbon bond (indicated in red in Figure 2).

Because both reactions utilize the same kind of starting materials, non-selective catalysts do catalyze both reactions concurrently, leading to product mixtures. In this study, this potential problem was overcome by developing rare-earth metal-based catalysts for the hydroamination reaction (Figure 1), which allowed this reaction to be performed with high selectivity with non-activated starting materials for the first time. A particular important outcome is that these novel catalysts produced the desired compounds with the correct handedness in a ratio of up to 83 to 17 between the image and its mirror image congener. In order to facilitate the hydroaminoalkylation reaction, a series of niobium- and tantalum-based catalysts were developed (Figure 2), which achieved this transformation with high selectivity, providing the desired product in an unprecedented image to mirror image product ratio of up to 99 to 1.

Both reactions developed in this study represent highly valuable and environmentally benign transformations that promise to revolutionize the synthesis of nitrogen containing molecules, with potential applications in the syntheses of nitrogen containing basic and fine chemicals, as well as pharmaceuticals, directly from petrochemical feedstock (Figure 3). The possibility to prepare different products from the same kind of starting materials, depending on the catalyst applied, is an important tool for synthetic chemists, as it allows faster and more efficient preparation of a more diverse set of target molecules.


Last Modified: 10/09/2017
Modified by: Kai C Hultzsch

Images (1 of )
  • The catalysts developed in this study allow the simple assembly of complex nitrogen containing molecules (?amines?) from simple and cheap starting materials in a highly economical and waste-free manner. In this so-called ?hydroamination? process, a new carbon-nitrogen bond (shown in red) is formed.
    Kai Hultzsch
    Copyrighted
    Kai C Hultzsch
    Figure 1
  • New catalysts developed in this study allow the assembly of substrates similar to those shown in Figure 1 in an alternative manner. This so-called ?hydroaminoalkylation? reaction leads to different nitrogen containing molecules with a newly formed carbon-carbon bond (shown in red).
    Kai Hultzsch
    Copyrighted
    Kai C Hultzsch
    Figure 2
  • Similar to a left and right hand, molecules can exist as image and mirror image. It is important that only one form is produced in this process, as the other form (the mirror image) may have undesired side effects in pharmaceuticals or pesticides.
    Kai Hultzsch
    Copyrighted
    Kai C Hultzsch
    Figure 3
